name: Whisky Highball
instructions:
1. Cut a lemon ready for garnishing and squeezing
2. Fill your highball with ice
3. Pour all the ingredients into your glass
4. Top up with soda water
5. Stir the drink gently together, mixing all the ingredients
6. Garnish with the lemon wedge
description: Initially, the most common highball was made with Scotch whisky and carbonated water, known simply as a "Scotch and soda". New York barman Patrick Duffy claimed the highball was brought to the U.S. in 1894 from England by actor E. J. Ratcliffe. Bartender Tip:Simple and refreshing cocktail with surprising complexity. One part whisky, two parts mixer, garnished with a lemon wedge and served over ice in a highball glass; the whisky highball is as simple as it is delicious

ingredients.name: Whiskey
ingredients.description:
Whiskey is a distilled alcoholic beverage made from fermented grain mash. The grains used in whiskey production can include barley, corn, rye, and wheat. The production process involves mashing the grains, fermenting the mash, distilling the liquid, and aging it in wooden barrels, usually made of oak. The aging process imparts flavors and character to the whiskey.

The flavor, aroma, and characteristics of whiskey can vary widely based on factors such as the type of grains used, the distillation process, the type of barrels used for aging, and the duration of maturation. Whiskey is enjoyed in various ways, including neat, on the rocks, or as a key ingredient in cocktails.

ingredients.name: Club soda

substitutes.name: Ginger ale
substitutes.description: Ginger ale is a non-alcoholic carbonated beverage flavored with ginger. It is known for its fizzy and slightly spicy taste, derived from the natural or artificial ginger flavorings used in its production. Ginger ale is often consumed on its own as a refreshing soft drink, and it is also a common mixer in various cocktails. There are both commercial and homemade versions of ginger ale, with variations that may include additional ingredients such as citrus or sweeteners.
